Highlights

  • Cognizant Expands Strategic Partnership with Google Cloud to Operationalize Agentic AI at Scale (Published: 2026-02-16)

    Cognizant’s latest announcement, detailed at Cognizant + Google Cloud news, marks a major step in operationalizing agentic AI for enterprise use cases. By marrying Google Cloud’s advanced AI stack with Cognizant’s consulting and vertical expertise, the two aim to expedite the development and deployment of intelligent agents in key functions like HR, finance, and healthcare. This sets a higher competitive benchmark for SaaS-native AI capabilities and urges Workday practitioners and Deloitte teams to closely monitor hyperscaler integration strategies and support rapid adoption for shared clients.

  • TechCrunch: The Enterprise AI Land Grab Accelerates as Glean Builds the 'Glue Layer' for Autonomous Agents (Published: 2026-02-15)

    TechCrunch reports a strategic evolution in enterprise AI platforms. Glean’s connective tissue approach to agent orchestration allows disparate SaaS apps and their agents to interoperate securely. Their emergence signals a new requirement for Workday, Oracle, and ServiceNow: ensure agentic features can ‘plug in’ to neutral, standards-based coordination frameworks. For Deloitte, this signals a client advisory pivot—highlighting futureproof architectures and reducing single-vendor exposure.

  • SiliconANGLE: TheCUBE Research 2026 Predictions—Enterprise ROI Comes to the Forefront (Published: 2026-02-15)

    SiliconANGLE’s annual research states that buyers now prioritize clear, repeatable business value from agentic and generative AI. Solutions are increasingly measured based on their automation scope, integration into HR/finance workflows, and post-go-live productivity results. The “so what” for Workday and Deloitte: be prepared with proven ROI analytics, value stories, and metrics that resonate with CFOs and HR leadership.

Competitive Watch

  • Cognizant + Google Cloud: Their expanded partnership is designed to accelerate agentic AI at enterprise scale, blending Google’s robust AI tools with Cognizant’s industry acumen. This leapfrogs many standalone SaaS vendors and could disrupt procurement priorities for joint Workday clients, especially if native integrations follow quickly. For Deloitte, keeping pace with Google Cloud agent pipelines is a must.
  • Glean: By launching a middleware layer for efficient, secure agent orchestration, Glean shapes the emerging competitive landscape—where the most flexible and interoperable platforms win. Deloitte’s Workday advisory must help clients assess not only vendor “agent IQ” but also their ecosystem openness and orchestration strategies.
  • TheCUBE/Industry Analyst Firms: A sharper focus on enterprise ROI will create a new basis for SaaS and agentic AI selection. This puts pressure on Deloitte and Workday engagements to deliver impact data and post-implementation analytics, not just technical configuration.

Enablement

  • Hyperscaler AI Agent Orchestration (Cognizant + Google Cloud): Upskill on Google Cloud Vertex AI and orchestrated agent solutions for rapid client implementations.
  • Agentic AI Ecosystem Mapping (TechCrunch/Glean): Develop fluency in emerging agentic middleware, helping clients futureproof HR tech choices.
  • Value Realization & ROI Attribution (SiliconANGLE): Build robust value cases and establish KPI tracking from day one.

Actions for Next Week

  • Refresh integration playbooks with the latest Google Cloud agentic AI tooling.
  • Host cross-disciplinary briefings on agentic AI orchestration platforms and implications for Workday environments.
  • Create fresh ROI showcases on agentic AI automations within HR operations for client-facing engagements.
  • Audit Deloitte's Workday advisory and implementation templates for open standards and extensibility recommendations.

Risks & Mitigations

  • Risk: A fragmented agentic AI landscape could drive vendor lock-in and data integration complexity.
    Mitigation: Embed open interface and agent orchestration requirements into all new client projects; escalate vendor-agnostic approaches in all alliances and advisory support.
  • Risk: Lack of ROI measurement in pilot phases could erode trust in agentic AI and stall broader adoption.
    Mitigation: Make clinched benefit tracking part of every engagement’s inception, with iterative reporting and roadmaps linked to measured outcomes.

All Sources

  • Cognizant Expands Strategic Partnership with Google Cloud to Operationalize Agentic AI at Enterprise Scale
  • The enterprise AI land grab is on. Glean is building the layer beneath the interface
  • TheCUBE Research 2026 predictions: The year of enterprise ROI

Return JSON ONLY in this exact shape (no code fences, no extra text):

{
  "type": "daily or weekly",
  "run_date": "YYYY-MM-DD",
  "title": "Short headline",
  "priority_focus": "1–2 sentences on what matters most now",
  "highlights": [
    { "headline": "…", "why_it_matters": "…", "source_url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "competitive_watch": [
    { "competitor": "Name", "move": "…", "implication": "…" }
  ],
  "enablement": [
    { "skill": "Topic", "resource_url": "https://…", "90_day_outcome": "…" }
  ],
  "actions_next_week": ["…"],
  "risks": [
    { "risk": "…", "mitigation": "…" }
  ],
  "sources": [
    { "title": "…", "url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "html_body": "<h2>…</h2> (well-formatted HTML with <a href="https://…">links</a>; no scripts/external CSS)",
  "plain_text_body": "Text-only with visible URLs"
}

Parameters:
- Set "run_date" to TODAY_ET = 2026-02-16.
- For DAILY: set "type":"daily"; target ~1000 words; STRICTLY restrict to the last 24 hours (from 2026-02-15T06:58 to 2026-02-16T06:58); include publication dates in highlight text.
- For WEEKLY: set "type":"weekly"; target 2000–2500 words; restrict to 2026-02-09…2026-02-16; include <h3>What changed this week</h3> and publication dates in highlight text.
- Section order for html_body: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Every item must include at least one absolute URL (https://…).
- Keep total HTML under ~25KB.

ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS
- For every highlight and competitive_watch item, include a 2–3 paragraph detailed summary within the "why_it_matters" text.
- Where relevant, compare perspectives across multiple sources.
- Include a clear "so what" statement for Deloitte’s Workday practice.
- Ensure all cited URLs appear in the `sources` array and inside the `html_body` link text.
- Keep factual accuracy and avoid speculation.

For Deloitte, keeping pace with Google Cloud agent pipelines is a must.<br/></li>\\n  <li><b>Glean</b>: By launching a middleware layer for efficient, secure agent orchestration, Glean shapes the emerging competitive landscape—where the most flexible and interoperable platforms win. Deloitte’s Workday advisory must help clients assess not only vendor “agent IQ” but also their ecosystem openness and orchestration strategies.<br/></li>\\n  <li><b>TheCUBE/Industry Analyst Firms</b>: A sharper focus on enterprise ROI will create a new basis for SaaS and agentic AI selection. This puts pressure on Deloitte and Workday engagements to deliver impact data and post-implementation analytics, not just technical configuration.<br/></li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h2>Enablement</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li><b>Hyperscaler AI Agent Orchestration</b> (<a href=\\\"https://news.cognizant.com/2026-02-16-Cognizant-Expands-Strategic-Partnership-with-Google-Cloud-to-Operationalize-Agentic-AI-at-Enterprise-Scale\\\">Cognizant + Google Cloud</a>): Upskill on Google Cloud Vertex AI and orchestrated agent solutions for rapid client implementations.</li>\\n  <li><b>Agentic AI Ecosystem Mapping</b> (<a href=\\\"https://techcrunch.com/2026/02/15/the-enterprise-ai-land-grab-is-on-glean-is-building-the-layer-beneath-the-interface\\\">TechCrunch/Glean</a>): Develop fluency in emerging agentic middleware, helping clients futureproof HR tech choices.</li>\\n  <li><b>Value Realization & ROI Attribution</b> (<a href=\\\"https://siliconangle.com/2026/02/15/thecube-research-2026-predictions-year-enterprise-roi\\\">SiliconANGLE</a>): Build robust value cases and establish KPI tracking from day one.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h2>Actions for Next Week</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li>Refresh integration playbooks with the latest Google Cloud agentic AI tooling.</li>\\n  <li>Host cross-disciplinary briefings on agentic AI orchestration platforms and implications for Workday environments.</li>\\n  <li>Create fresh ROI showcases on agentic AI automations within HR operations for client-facing engagements.</li>\\n  <li>Audit Deloitte's Workday advisory and implementation templates for open standards and extensibility recommendations.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h2>Risks & Mitigations</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li><b>Risk:</b> A fragmented agentic AI landscape could drive vendor lock-in and data integration complexity.<br/>\\n      <b>Mitigation:</b> Embed open interface and agent orchestration requirements into all new client projects; escalate vendor-agnostic approaches in all alliances and advisory support.</li>\\n  <li><b>Risk:</b> Lack of ROI measurement in pilot phases could erode trust in agentic AI and stall broader adoption.<br/>\\n      <b>Mitigation:</b> Make clinched benefit tracking part of every engagement’s inception, with iterative reporting and roadmaps linked to measured outcomes.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h2>All Sources</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li><a href=\\\"https://news.cognizant.com/2026-02-16-Cognizant-Expands-Strategic-Partnership-with-Google-Cloud-to-Operationalize-Agentic-AI-at-Enterprise-Scale\\\">Cognizant Expands Strategic Partnership with Google Cloud to Operationalize Agentic AI at Enterprise Scale</a></li>\\n  <li><a href=\\\"https://techcrunch.com/2026/02/15/the-enterprise-ai-land-grab-is-on-glean-is-building-the-layer-beneath-the-interface\\\">The enterprise AI land grab is on. Glean is building the layer beneath the interface</a></li>\\n  <li><a href=\\\"https://siliconangle.com/2026/02/15/thecube-research-2026-predictions-year-enterprise-roi\\\">TheCUBE Research 2026 predictions: The year of enterprise ROI</a></li>\\n</ul>\",\n  \"plain_text_body\": \"Highlights\\n- Cognizant Expands Strategic Partnership with Google Cloud to Operationalize Agentic AI at Scale (Published: 2026-02-16)\\nCognizant’s latest announcement, detailed at https://news.cognizant.com/2026-02-16-Cognizant-Expands-Strategic-Partnership-with-Google-Cloud-to-Operationalize-Agentic-AI-at-Enterprise-Scale, marks a major step in operationalizing agentic AI for enterprise use cases. By marrying Google Cloud’s advanced AI stack with Cognizant’s consulting and vertical expertise, the two aim to expedite the development and deployment of intelligent agents in key functions like HR, finance, and healthcare. This sets a higher competitive benchmark for SaaS-native AI capabilities and urges Workday practitioners and Deloitte teams to closely monitor hyperscaler integration strategies and support rapid adoption for shared clients.\\n\\n- TechCrunch: The Enterprise AI Land Grab Accelerates as Glean Builds the 'Glue Layer' for Autonomous Agents (Published: 2026-02-15)\\nTechCrunch (https://techcrunch.com/2026/02/15/the-enterprise-ai-land-grab-is-on-glean-is-building-the-layer-beneath-the-interface) reports that Glean is addressing the next frontier of enterprise AI: seamless agent orchestration. Their platform acts as the connective infrastructure that allows autonomous agents from various SaaS platforms to cooperate and interoperate. This shift signals that proprietary, closed agent platforms may risk obsolescence if open coordination frameworks proliferate. For Workday, this means ensuring agentic features can ‘plug in’ to third-party middleware; for Deloitte, client architectural and procurement guidance must shift accordingly.\\n\\n- SiliconANGLE: TheCUBE Research 2026 Predictions—Enterprise ROI Comes to the Forefront (Published: 2026-02-15)\\nSiliconANGLE’s (https://siliconangle.com/2026/02/15/thecube-research-2026-predictions-year-enterprise-roi) annual outlook identifies ROI as the new axis of agentic AI competition. Enterprise buyers now demand proofs of repeatable business value from AI and automation in HR/finance. Workday and Deloitte practitioners must be prepared to provide demonstrable ROI analytics and real-world automation metrics.\\n\\nCompetitive Watch\\n- Cognizant + Google Cloud: Announced a wide-ranging partnership to bring agentic AI into enterprise workflows using Google Cloud's AI stack (https://news.cognizant.com/2026-02-16-Cognizant-Expands-Strategic-Partnership-with-Google-Cloud-to-Operationalize-Agentic-AI-at-Enterprise-Scale). This could disrupt Workday’s position in automation and heightens Deloitte’s need for technical integration expertise with major hyperscalers.\\n- Glean: Building a middleware coordination platform for autonomous agents across SaaS (https://techcrunch.com/2026/02/15/the-enterprise-ai-land-grab-is-on-glean-is-building-the-layer-beneath-the-interface). This creates new integration dependencies for Workday, Oracle, and ServiceNow environments.\\n- TheCUBE/Analysts: Demand for outcome-driven, ROI-based AI procurement (https://siliconangle.com/2026/02/15/thecube-research-2026-predictions-year-enterprise-roi) is rising, putting pressure on vendors and implementers alike.\\n\\nEnablement\\n- Hyperscaler AI Agent Orchestration: Upskill on Google Cloud (https://news.cognizant.com/2026-02-16-Cognizant-Expands-Strategic-Partnership-with-Google-Cloud-to-Operationalize-Agentic-AI-at-Enterprise-Scale) for rapid agent-based solution deployments.\\n- Agentic AI Ecosystem Mapping: Learn about agentic middleware and its procurement implications (https://techcrunch.com/2026/02/15/the-enterprise-ai-land-grab-is-on-glean-is-building-the-layer-beneath-the-interface).\\n- Value Realization and ROI Attribution: Practice rigorous benefits tracking for agentic AI (https://siliconangle.com/2026/02/15/thecube-research-2026-predictions-year-enterprise-roi).\\n\\nActions for Next Week\\n- Update Workday + Google Cloud integration playbooks.\\n- Host internal knowledge share on agentic AI orchestration and its implications for SaaS clients.\\n- Build new case studies showcasing agentic AI-driven productivity gains.\\n- Audit internal templates to ensure coverage of open standards and extensibility.\\n\\nRisks & Mitigations\\n- Risk: Agentic AI fragmentation may increase lock-in and data friction for clients. Mitigation: Advocate open-standards and middleware interoperability at every advisory touchpoint.\\n- Risk: Over-investment in pilots without ROI focus risks program stagnation. Mitigation: Embed value-tracking and iterative reporting from day one.\\n\\nAll Sources\\n- Cognizant Expands Strategic Partnership with Google Cloud to Operationalize Agentic AI at Enterprise Scale: https://news.cognizant.com/2026-02-16-Cognizant-Expands-Strategic-Partnership-with-Google-Cloud-to-Operationalize-Agentic-AI-at-Enterprise-Scale\\n- The enterprise AI land grab is on. [...] to act with greater confidence and agility. As a result, organizations can reduce friction, make faster decisions, and increase speed to market. Next, agentic AI begins to take over entire workflows, acting autonomously with minimal human oversight. And with full AI transformation, the risk function itself is reimagined — traditional methods are replaced with AI-native strategies that are faster, more precise, and deeply data-driven. [...] The organizations pulling ahead are those that treat AI not as a bolt-on, but as a strategic capability. They’re redesigning their operating models around the analytical risk management moments that matter and using AI automation — with a human-in-the-loop, by design — to speed up and strengthen data analysis and reallocate human capital to higher-value work. They’re not just using AI — they’re using it well. Importantly, AI is also leveling the playing field: It offers a powerful opportunity for smaller organizations to compete with larger ones by democratizing access to advanced analytics and decision-making tools that were once the domain of only the biggest players.",

      "content": "print(\"\\nGoodbye!\") break # Stream the agent's response print(\"Agent: \", end=\"\", flush=True) # Track tool calls to avoid duplicate prints seen\\_tools = set() async for update in agent.run\\_stream(user\\_message, thread=conversation\\_thread): # Display text content if update.text: print(update.text, end=\"\", flush=True) # Display tool calls and results for content in update.contents: if isinstance(content, FunctionCallContent): # Only print each tool call once if content.call\\_id not in seen\\_tools: seen\\_tools.add(content.call\\_id) print(f\"\\n[Calling tool: {content.name}]\", flush=True) elif isinstance(content, FunctionResultContent): # Only print each result once result\\_id = f\"result\\_{content.call\\_id}\" if result\\_id not in seen\\_tools: seen\\_tools.add(result\\_id) result\\_text = [...] {\"status\": \"shipped\", \"tracking\": \"1Z999AA1\", \"eta\": \"Jan 25, 2026\"}] Your order ORD-001 has been shipped! - Tracking Number: 1Z999AA1 - Estimated Delivery Date: January 25, 2026 You can use the tracking number to monitor the delivery progress. You: Can you check ORD-002? Agent: [Calling tool: get\\_order\\_status] [Tool result: {\"status\": \"processing\", \"tracking\": null, \"eta\": \"Jan 23, 2026\"}] Your order ORD-002 is currently being processed. - Status: Processing - Estimated Delivery: January 23, 2026 Your order should ship soon, and you'll receive a tracking number once it's on the way.       "title": "Royal Greenland CIO: “We Want to Consume Standardized AI, Not ...",
      "content": "## Technology first, innovation next\n\nGo‑live is planned for March 1, 2027. The year 2026 is dedicated to the platform lift itself. From 2027, Royal Greenland will begin building business‑driven improvements on top of the standardized core—for example, new user interfaces and process optimization using small AI agents within finance and administration.\n\n“Royal Greenland and SAP have worked together since 1998, and we look forward to getting started on the technical part of the platform uplift this January,” Hassinggaard shared. “We’re keeping the transformation as simple as possible for now and will use 2027 to activate the benefits, such as improved data analysis, better user experience, and more efficient work processes.” [...] “We are a company that prefers to tap into existing AI solutions rather than invent them ourselves,” Hassinggaard said. “It’s far more efficient for us. There is no reason for us to spend resources reinventing what SAP already provides. The initial focus will be on process optimization within administrative functions such as finance—small AI agents that can streamline daily work.”\n\n## Advice to others: Allocate more time, and understand your method\n\nHassinggaard is clear that the RISE with SAP contract, methodology, and preparation work require time and organizational maturity. His advice to other companies facing a similar cloud ERP decision: “Do it thoroughly—and allocate more time than you think. Study the methodology, pricing, and contracts.     {
      "url": "https://venturebeat.com/infrastructure/nvidia-groq-and-the-limestone-race-to-real-time-ai-why-enterprises-win-or",
      "title": "Nvidia, Groq and the limestone race to real-time AI - VentureBeat",
      "content": "### ​The engine for the next wave of growth\n\n​For the C-Suite, this potential convergence solves the \"thinking time\" latency crisis. Consider the expectations from AI agents: We want them to autonomously book flights, code entire apps and research legal precedent. To do this reliably, a model might need to generate 10,000 internal \"thought tokens\" to verify its own work before it outputs a single word to the user.\n\n ​On a standard GPU: 10,000 thought tokens might take 20 to 40 seconds. The user gets bored and leaves.\n ​On Groq: That same chain of thought happens in less than 2 seconds. [...] ​Do you remember where you recently saw this technique mentioned? Nvidia’s Rubin press release: The technology includes “...the latest generations of Nvidia NVLink interconnect technology... to accelerate agentic AI, advanced reasoning and massive-scale MoE model inference at up to 10x lower cost per token.”\n\n​Jensen knows that achieving that coveted exponential growth in compute doesn’t come from pure brute force anymore. Sometimes you need to shift the architecture entirely to place the next stepping stone.\n\n### ​The latency crisis: Where Groq fits in\n\n​This long introduction brings us to Groq. [...] ​Training requires massive parallel brute force. Inference, especially for reasoning models, requires faster sequential processing. It must generate tokens instantly to facilitate complex chains of thought without the user waiting minutes for an answer. ​Groq’s LPU (Language Processing Unit) architecture removes the memory bandwidth bottleneck that plagues GPUs during small-batch inference, delivering lightning-fast inference.\n\n### ​The engine for the next wave of growth",
      "score": 0.19980752,
      "raw_content": null

      "content": "Artificial Intelligence and Autonomous Digital Systems:HaDEA is looking for experts with in-depth knowledge of artificial intelligence, particularly in the development and application of next-generation AI systems and agents. This includes expertise in agentic AI architectures, autonomous and adaptive systems, multi-agent systems, trustworthy and explainable AI, and the deployment of AI solutions in real-world application domains such as industry, mobility, health, energy or public services. [...] Digital-Physical Integration and System Engineering: Experts with a system-level perspective on digital-physical integration are also needed. This includes experience in cyber-physical systems, embedded intelligence, integration of AI and robotics with physical components, and end-to-end system engineering approaches enabling robust, scalable and interoperable solutions.\n\nFor further information on the digital calls, please see the recordings of the Horizon Europe Cluster 4 Info Days (sensing technologies, AI agents, and intelligent robotics) or consult the Horizon Europe Work Programme 2026-2027.\n\nHaDEA welcomes applications from experts from academia, research organisations, industry, SMEs and public bodies, including those with interdisciplinary and cross-sector experience. Cluster 4: Digital, Industry and Space supports research and innovation across advanced digital technologies, industrial leadership and strategic autonomy, contributing to Europe’s long-term competitiveness and resilience. Time range: day

      "content": "UPDATED 12:00 EST / SEPTEMBER 16 2025\n\n### Workday acquires Sana Labs for $1.1B to upgrade agentic AI work experiences\n\nby  Kyt Dotson\n\nHuman resources and finance software giant Workday Inc. today announced the acquisition of Sana Labs AB, an artificial intelligence company offering enterprise knowledge and employee training tools, for about $1.1 billion.\n\nWorkday also announced new AI agents for HR, finance and industry use cases in its Illuminate platform alongside a new developer platform, including a low-code agent builder that will allow customers to deploy custom AI agents. [...] ### Workday upgrades its AI agents and work tools\n\nIn addition to today’s acquisition news, Workday also announced new AI agents, including a Financial Close Agent and Case Agent, purpose-built for complex business processes like performance reviews, planning and assisting with financial use cases.\n\nThe new agents are part of Workday Illuminate, Workday’s AI platform. The company said the new agents are “purpose-built for work,” embedded with their respective industry use cases and powered by deep insights into business data and context. [...] For use cases not covered by these agents and Workday’s already existing AI agents, the company today announced Workday Build, a new developer platform that gives customers and partners the power to create and deploy their own AI-powered solutions. It includes Flowise Agent Builder, a low-code tool that makes building agents on the company’s platform simple for both non-technical and advanced users.\n\n“The era of one-size-fits-all enterprise software is over,” said Peter Bailis, chief technology officer at Workday. “With Workday Build, customers go from consuming AI to creating with it, giving them the power to build intelligent solutions directly on their most trusted people and financial data.”",

    {
      "url": "https://blog.workday.com/en-us/ai-agents-in-healthcare-top-trends-and-use-cases.html",
      "title": "AI Agents in Healthcare: Top Trends and Use Cases | Workday",
      "content": "Workday is also advancing agentic AI capabilities tailored to healthcare operations through its Agent System of Record. In settings where staffing, scheduling, and financial planning are tightly connected, the Agent System of Record enables agents to act on real-time data from across HR and finance systems, supporting key decisions like adjusting shift coverage based on patient volume, labor costs, or credentialing requirements.\n\nCredentialing is another space where agents are showing value. Instead of relying on spreadsheet tracking and periodic audits, health systems are deploying agents to monitor license renewals, training completions, and policy compliance in real time—reducing risk and administrative burden. [...] ## What’s Next: Putting Agentic AI into Action\n\nAgentic AI is becoming embedded into the operational and clinical systems that healthcare teams use every day. Across key healthcare AI applications like scheduling, documentation, credentialing, treatment planning, and research workflows, early deployments are showing where agentic AI can reduce friction and support faster and more informed decisions that drive outcomes.\n\nBut deployment is only part of the challenge. Real impact depends on how well AI-powered systems are governed, how clearly their purpose is defined, and how effectively they’re integrated into the environments they’re meant to support. That includes aligning with the realities of care delivery, data infrastructure, and oversight requirements. [...] In healthcare, even more so than other industries, agentic AI has an important dual impact: it helps to both optimize healthcare operations and efficiencies while powering scalable high-quality care provision. In clinical settings, agents help maintain continuity by adapting to real-time patient conditions, minimizing gaps in care, and aligning actions to treatment goals. On the operational side, they support dynamic resource allocation, reduce bottlenecks, and bring coordination into daily decision-making.",

Instead of relying on spreadsheet tracking and periodic audits, health systems are deploying agents to monitor license renewals, training completions, and policy compliance in real time—reducing risk and administrative burden. [...] ## What’s Next: Putting Agentic AI into Action\n\nAgentic AI is becoming embedded into the operational and clinical systems that healthcare teams use every day. Across key healthcare AI applications like scheduling, documentation, credentialing, treatment planning, and research workflows, early deployments are showing where agentic AI can reduce friction and support faster and more informed decisions that drive outcomes.\n\nBut deployment is only part of the challenge. Real impact depends on how well AI-powered systems are governed, how clearly their purpose is defined, and how effectively they’re integrated into the environments they’re meant to support. That includes aligning with the realities of care delivery, data infrastructure, and oversight requirements. [...] In healthcare, even more so than other industries, agentic AI has an important dual impact: it helps to both optimize healthcare operations and efficiencies while powering scalable high-quality care provision. In clinical settings, agents help maintain continuity by adapting to real-time patient conditions, minimizing gaps in care, and aligning actions to treatment goals. On the operational side, they support dynamic resource allocation, reduce bottlenecks, and bring coordination into daily decision-making.",

      "url": "https://blog.workday.com/en-sg/ai-agents-for-hr-top-use-cases-and-examples.html",
      "title": "AI Agents for HR: Top Use Cases and Examples | Workday SG",
      "content": "Agentic AI for HR fills the gap. It can interpret nuance, make decisions dynamically, and take initiative across multi-step processes, offloading the complexity that BPA wasn’t built to handle. For example: Agents can identify when a benefits request doesn’t follow the usual path or when a policy requires clarification and either make the adjustment itself or flag the issue to a human to handle it.\n\nSome of the areas where HR agents are already providing essential support:\n\n Screening job applicants and scheduling interviews\n Handling PTO, benefits, and policy-related requests\n Delivering onboarding, offboarding, and training experiences\n Monitoring engagement and surfacing retention risks\n Assisting in workforce planning and modeling [...] When deployed properly, AI agents open up capacity for HR teams to be more strategic and build better relationships. Agents can handle the administrative load without requiring constant oversight, which allows HR professionals to focus on more complex, human-centric responsibilities like coaching, retention, and culture. In this way, agentic AI represents an opportunity to enhance employee performance, rather than replace them. [...] ### 2. Employee Engagement and Workforce Management\n\nOnce an employee is hired, agents can support them throughout the onboarding journey. Provisioning, policy acknowledgment, training reminders, and basic Q&A can all be handled by AI agents acting as always-on support. Agents can also personalize the employee onboarding experience based on role, region, or manager, ensuring consistency without sacrificing nuance.",

    {
      "url": "https://blog.workday.com/en-us/posts/top-ai-agent-examples-and-industry-use-cases.html",
      "title": "Top AI Agent Examples and Industry Use Cases | Workday",
      "content": "According to the Workday research, 83% of workers believe that AI can boost their careers by helping them develop new skills in their roles and focus on more meaningful work. These findings reflect a growing shift: AI agents are not just tools of efficiency, but enablers of deeper human contribution.\n\nRather than displace jobs, agentic AI changes the nature of work. Agents take on repeatable, decision-bound tasks that follow clear logic or structured workflows. In doing so, they free up people to focus on work centered on creativity, intuition, innovation, and the ability to adapt amidst change and uncertainty.\n\nThis shift raises new requirements for how organizations design work. [...] > Leaders should map potential AI agent use cases using two key factors: strategic value and readiness for automation.\n\n## How to Select Agentic AI Use Cases\n\nWhile agentic AI systems are increasingly powerful, their impact depends on how thoughtfully they are applied. Choosing the right use cases is one of the most important steps in any agent deployment strategy.\n\nIdentifying the right AI agent functionality for your business is not just about what can be automated—it’s about where agents can deliver meaningful business value with clarity and control.\n\nThe best use cases tend to share three characteristics:\n\n Clear goals that agents can pursue autonomously\n Access to clean, structured data\n Repeatable logic that guides decisions or actions [...] Several core capabilities make an AI system agentic:\n\n Autonomy: The ability to operate independently within defined boundaries, without constant human instruction.\n Goal orientation: Agents pursue clear outcomes, evaluating actions based on how well they advance those goals.\n Adaptability: They monitor real-time inputs and adjust decisions dynamically as context shifts.\n Reasoning: Agents assess trade-offs, apply rules or models, and choose actions that reflect logical prioritization.\n Learning: Some agents can refine their behavior over time by analyzing the outcomes of past decisions.\n Collaboration: In multi-agent systems, agents coordinate and share knowledge to solve problems collectively.",
      "score": 0.7606688,
      "raw_content": null

These findings reflect a growing shift: AI agents are not just tools of efficiency, but enablers of deeper human contribution.\n\nRather than displace jobs, agentic AI changes the nature of work. Agents take on repeatable, decision-bound tasks that follow clear logic or structured workflows. In doing so, they free up people to focus on work centered on creativity, intuition, innovation, and the ability to adapt amidst change and uncertainty.\n\nThis shift raises new requirements for how organizations design work. [...] > Leaders should map potential AI agent use cases using two key factors: strategic value and readiness for automation.\n\n## How to Select Agentic AI Use Cases\n\nWhile agentic AI systems are increasingly powerful, their impact depends on how thoughtfully they are applied. Choosing the right use cases is one of the most important steps in any agent deployment strategy.\n\nIdentifying the right AI agent functionality for your business is not just about what can be automated—it’s about where agents can deliver meaningful business value with clarity and control.\n\nThe best use cases tend to share three characteristics:\n\n Clear goals that agents can pursue autonomously\n Access to clean, structured data\n Repeatable logic that guides decisions or actions [...] Several core capabilities make an AI system agentic:\n\n Autonomy: The ability to operate independently within defined boundaries, without constant human instruction.\n Goal orientation: Agents pursue clear outcomes, evaluating actions based on how well they advance those goals.\n Adaptability: They monitor real-time inputs and adjust decisions dynamically as context shifts.\n Reasoning: Agents assess trade-offs, apply rules or models, and choose actions that reflect logical prioritization.\n Learning: Some agents can refine their behavior over time by analyzing the outcomes of past decisions.\n Collaboration: In multi-agent systems, agents coordinate and share knowledge to solve problems collectively.",

These findings reflect a growing shift: AI agents are not just tools of efficiency, but enablers of deeper human contribution.\n\nRather than displace jobs, agentic AI changes the nature of work. Agents take on repeatable, decision-bound tasks that follow clear logic or structured workflows. In doing so, they free up people to focus on work centered on creativity, intuition, innovation, and the ability to adapt amidst change and uncertainty.\n\nThis shift raises new requirements for how organizations design work. [...] > Leaders should map potential AI agent use cases using two key factors: strategic value and readiness for automation.\n\n## How to Select Agentic AI Use Cases\n\nWhile agentic AI systems are increasingly powerful, their impact depends on how thoughtfully they are applied. Choosing the right use cases is one of the most important steps in any agent deployment strategy.\n\nIdentifying the right AI agent functionality for your business is not just about what can be automated—it’s about where agents can deliver meaningful business value with clarity and control.\n\nThe best use cases tend to share three characteristics:\n\n Clear goals that agents can pursue autonomously\n Access to clean, structured data\n Repeatable logic that guides decisions or actions [...] Several core capabilities make an AI system agentic:\n\n Autonomy: The ability to operate independently within defined boundaries, without constant human instruction.\n Goal orientation: Agents pursue clear outcomes, evaluating actions based on how well they advance those goals.\n Adaptability: They monitor real-time inputs and adjust decisions dynamically as context shifts.\n Reasoning: Agents assess trade-offs, apply rules or models, and choose actions that reflect logical prioritization.\n Learning: Some agents can refine their behavior over time by analyzing the outcomes of past decisions.\n Collaboration: In multi-agent systems, agents coordinate and share knowledge to solve problems collectively.",

      "url": "https://assets.kpmg.com/content/dam/kpmgsites/xx/pdf/2026/02/ai-in-risk-management.pdf",
      "title": "[PDF] risk management - KPMG agentic corporate services",
      "content": "AI can help deliver transformative value across various stages of the risk management lifecycle, from risk identification to risk review and reporting. Here are some not-so-obvious use cases your organization can start exploring right now: AI use cases through the risk management lifecycle Risk identification: AI can generate process flows, detect emerging risks, and recommend mappings to risk taxonomies, processes, and controls. This helps organizations identify risks more accurately and earlier.\nRisk assessment: AI can recommend risk ratings, generate and monitor key risk indicators, and calculate residual risk. By making risk assessment more probabilistic, AI can enhance the precision and consistency of risk ratings. [...] KPMG Workbench KPMG has collaborated with Microsoft to build KPMG Workbench on Microsoft Azure AI Foundry services, allowing for interoperable, agent-to-agent communications. In addition, it brings together capabilities from across the KPMG ecosystem of alliance partners, such as ServiceNow, Salesforce and Workday, so clients accessing it can choose the model or AI agent that fits their task. [...] Pilot with purpose: Don’t try to boil the ocean. Choose one or two high-impact use cases and run parallel pilots. Compare AI-driven outcomes to traditional methods. If the results are as good, or better, then use that evidence to build internal confidence and regulatory credibility. Tip: Learn from early adopters in credit and fraud risk. Their success with AI-powered decisioning has already earned regulatory comfort.",

      "content": "Freigegebener Schlüssel: Der Zugriffsschlüssel für Azure Blob Storage.\n\nKlicken Sie auf Weiter.\n\nPrüfen Sie die neue Feedkonfiguration auf dem Bildschirm Abschließen und klicken Sie dann auf Senden.\n\n## UDM-Zuordnungstabelle [...] Google Cloud Documentation\n\nGoogle Cloud Documentation\n\n# Microsoft Graph-Aktivitätsprotokolle erfassen\n\n## Übersicht\n\nDieser Parser extrahiert Felder aus Microsoft Graph-Aktivitätslogs und wandelt sie in das Unified Data Model (UDM) um. Es initialisiert UDM-Felder, parst die Nutzlast, extrahiert Zeitstempel, ordnet verschiedene Eigenschaften UDM-Feldern zu, verarbeitet IP-Adressen und Ports und kategorisiert den Ereignistyp anhand der vorhandenen Haupt- und Netzwerkinformationen.\n\n## Hinweise\n\nPrüfen Sie, ob die folgenden Voraussetzungen erfüllt sind:\n\n## Azure-Speicherkonto konfigurieren\n\nBewahren Sie den Schlüssel an einem sicheren Ort auf, damit Sie später darauf zugreifen können. Les informations de ce document s'appliquent au parseur avec le libellé d'ingestion `GCP_NETWORK_CONNECTIVITY_CONTEXT`.\n\nPour en savoir plus sur les autres analyseurs de contexte compatibles avec Google SecOps, consultez Analyseurs de contexte Google SecOps.\n\n## Formats de journaux Network Connectivity Center acceptés\n\nL'analyseur Network Connectivity Center est compatible avec les journaux au format JSON.\n\n## Exemples de journaux Network Connectivity Center compatibles\n\n JSON : [...] Passer au contenu principal \n\nConsole  \n\n English\n Deutsch\n Español – América Latina\n Français\n Indonesia\n Italiano\n Português – Brasil\n 中文 – 简体\n 中文 – 繁體\n 日本語\n 한국어\n  Connexion\n\n Google Security Operations\n\nCommencer l'essai gratuit\n\n \n\n Home\n Documentation\n Security\n Google Security Operations\n Guides\n\n    Restez organisé à l'aide des collections   Enregistrez et classez les contenus selon vos préférences.    \n\n# Collecter les journaux de contexte Network Connectivity Center\n\nCe document décrit comment les champs des journaux de contexte Network Connectivity Center sont mappés aux champs du modèle de données unifié (UDM) de Google Security Operations. Der Parser extrahiert Felder aus Syslog-formatierten Logs von Aruba Central. Die Log-Nachricht wird mit „grok“ und/oder „kv“ geparst und die Werte werden dem Unified Data Model (UDM) zugeordnet. Damit werden Standardmetadatenwerte für die Ereignisquelle und den Ereignistyp festgelegt.\n\n## Hinweise\n\nPrüfen Sie, ob folgende Voraussetzungen erfüllt sind:\n\n# Authentifizierungsdatei für die Aufnahme in Google SecOps abrufen\n\n## Google SecOps-Kundennummer abrufen\n\n## BindPlane-Agent installieren [...] ## BindPlane-Agent installieren\n\nInstallieren Sie den Bindplane-Agent auf Ihrem Windows- oder Linux-Betriebssystem gemäß der folgenden Anleitung.\n\n### Fenstereinbau\n\nFühren Sie dazu diesen Befehl aus:\n\n`msiexec /i \" /quiet`\n\n### Linux-Installation\n\nFühren Sie dazu diesen Befehl aus:\n\n`sudo sh -c \"$(curl -fsSlL  install_unix.sh`\n\n### Zusätzliche Installationsressourcen\n\nWeitere Installationsoptionen finden Sie im Installationsleitfaden.\n\n## BindPlane-Agent zum Erfassen von Syslog-Daten und Senden an Google SecOps konfigurieren\n\n`config.yaml`\n`/etc/bindplane-agent/`\n`nano`\n`vi`\n\nBearbeiten Sie die Datei `config.yaml`so:",

      "title": "收集Network Connectivity Center 內容記錄",
      "content": "Google Cloud Documentation\n\nGoogle Cloud Documentation\n\n# 收集 Network Connectivity Center 內容記錄\n\n本文說明 Network Connectivity Center 環境記錄的欄位如何對應至 Google Security Operations 整合式資料模型 (UDM) 欄位。\n\n擷取標籤會識別剖析器，該剖析器會將原始記錄資料正規化為具結構性的 UDM 格式。本文件中的資訊適用於具有 `GCP_NETWORK_CONNECTIVITY_CONTEXT` 攝入標籤的剖析器。\n\n`GCP_NETWORK_CONNECTIVITY_CONTEXT`\n\n如要瞭解 Google SecOps 支援的其他內容剖析器，請參閱「Google SecOps 內容剖析器」。\n\n## 支援的 Network Connectivity Center 記錄格式\n\n網路連線中心剖析器支援 JSON 格式的記錄。\n\n## 支援的 Network Connectivity Center 記錄範例\n\nJSON： [...] ## 支援的 Network Connectivity Center 記錄範例\n\nJSON：\n\n`{\n\"name\": \"//networkconnectivity.googleapis.com/projects/chronicle-dpa-test/locations/global/hubs/test-hub\",\n\"assetType\": \"networkconnectivity.googleapis.com/Hub\",\n\"resource\": {\n\"version\": \"v1\",\n\"discoveryDocumentUri\": \"\n\"discoveryName\": \"Hub\",\n\"parent\": \"//cloudresourcemanager.googleapis.com/projects/582699623097\",\n\"data\": {\n\"createTime\": \"2023-04-11T05:55:13.736577927Z\",\n\"name\": \"projects/chronicle-dpa-test/locations/global/hubs/test-hub\",\n\"state\": \"ACTIVE\",\n\"uniqueId\": \"3d6022bc-9306-4f4d-9d79-07b86836dee5\",\n\"updateTime\": \"2023-04-11T05:55:16.814218398Z\"\n}\n},\n\"ancestors\": [\n\"projects/582699623097\",\n\"organizations/383339652788\"\n]\n}`\n\n## 欄位對應參考資料 [...] ## 欄位對應參考資料\n\n下表說明 Google SecOps 剖析器如何將 Network Connectivity Center 內容記錄欄位對應至 Google SecOps 統合式資料模型 (UDM) 欄位。",

Go to Settings > Plugins.\n2. Search for and select the Netskope (CLS) box to open the plugin creation page.\n3. Enter the following details:\n    Configuration Name: enter a memorable name for this plugin.\n    Tenant: select the tenant you created in the previous step from the list.\n    Click Next.\n    Update the Event Type list as needed.\n    Initial Range: enter the amount of historical data you would like to ingest (in hours).\n    Click Save.\n\n## Configure a Google SecOps plugin in Netskope [...] Supported in:\n\nGoogle secops   SIEM\n\nThis parser handles both CEF and non-CEF formatted Netskope web proxy logs. It extracts fields, performs data transformations (for example, converting timestamps or merging fields), maps them to the UDM, and adds Netskope-specific metadata. The parser uses conditional logic to handle different log formats and field availability, enriching the UDM with relevant network, security, and application details.\n\n## Before you begin\n\n Ensure that you have a Google Security Operations instance.\n Ensure that you have privileged access to Netskope.\n Ensure that you have a configured Log Shipper module.\n Ensure that you have a Google SecOps service account key (reach out to the Google SecOps team to get a service account with the following scopes:",

This ultimately means businesses must do whatever they can to protect their own interests.\n\nOne such way that employers look to achieve this competitive edge is through a contractual mechanism called 'gardening leave', which acts as a contractual provision that prevents employees from working during their notice period whilst keeping them on full pay.\n\nTable of Contents\n\n## What is gardening leave?\n\nGardening leave refers to the period during which an employee who has resigned or been terminated remains on the company payroll but is not required to be at the workplace or continue working on any projects related to their role.       "content": "This is the new CloudFormation Template Reference Guide.\nPlease update your bookmarks and links. For help getting started with CloudFormation, see the\nAWS CloudFormation User Guide.\n\n# AWS::VerifiedPermissions::PolicyStore KmsEncryptionSettings\n\nA structure that contains the KMS encryption configuration for the policy store. The\nencryption settings determine what customer-managed KMS key will be used to encrypt\nall resources within the policy store, and any user-defined context key-value pairs to append\nduring encryption processes.\n\nThis data type is used as a field that is part of the EncryptionSettings\ntype.\n\n## Syntax\n\nTo declare this entity in your CloudFormation template, use the following syntax:\n\n### JSON [...] Required: Yes\n\nType: String\n\nPattern: `^[a-zA-Z0-9:/_-]+$`\n\n`^[a-zA-Z0-9:/_-]+$`\n\nUpdate requires: No interruption\n\nWarning Javascript is disabled or is unavailable in your browser.\n\nWarning\n\nTo use the Amazon Web Services Documentation, Javascript must be enabled. The\nencryption state shows what customer-managed KMS key is being used to encrypt\nall resources within the policy store, and any user-defined context key-value pairs added\nduring encryption processes.\n\nThis data type is used as a field that is part of the EncryptionState\ntype.\n\n## Syntax\n\nTo declare this entity in your CloudFormation template, use the following syntax:\n\n### JSON [...] ### JSON\n\n`{\n\"EncryptionContext\" : {Key: Value, ...},\n\"Key\" : String\n}`\n`{Key: Value, ...}`\n`Key`\n`Value`\n`String`\n\n### YAML\n\n `EncryptionContext: \nKey: Value\nKey: String`\n`Key: Value`\n`Key`\n`Value`\n`String`\n\n## Properties\n\n`EncryptionContext`\n\nUser-defined, additional context added to encryption processes.\n\nRequired: Yes\n\nType: Object of String\n\nPattern: `^.+$`\n\n`^.+$`\n\nMinimum: `1`\n\n`1`\n\nUpdate requires: No interruption\n\n`Key`\n\nThe customer-managed KMS key Amazon Resource Name (ARN) being used for encryption processes.\n\nRequired: Yes\n\nType: String\n\nPattern: `^[a-zA-Z0-9:/_-]+$`\n\n`^[a-zA-Z0-9:/_-]+$`\n\nUpdate requires: No interruption\n\nWarning Javascript is disabled or is unavailable in your browser.\n\nWarning [...] Warning\n\nTo use the Amazon Web Services Documentation, Javascript must be enabled.       "content": "## Properties\n\n`Default`\n\nThis is the default encryption state. The policy store is encrypted using an AWS owned key.\n\nRequired: No\n\nType: Json\n\nUpdate requires: No interruption\n\n`KmsEncryptionState`\n\nThe AWS KMS encryption settings currently configured for this policy store to encrypt data with.\nIt contains the customer-managed KMS key, and a user-defined encryption context.\n\nRequired: No\n\nType: KmsEncryptionState\n\nUpdate requires: No interruption\n\nWarning Javascript is disabled or is unavailable in your browser.\n\nWarning\n\nTo use the Amazon Web Services Documentation, Javascript must be enabled. Please refer to your browser's Help pages for instructions.\n\nThanks for letting us know we're doing a good job!\n\nIf you've got a moment, please tell us what we did right so we can do more of it. [...] Thanks for letting us know this page needs work. We're sorry we let you down.\n\nIf you've got a moment, please tell us how we can make the documentation better. [...] This is the new CloudFormation Template Reference Guide.\nPlease update your bookmarks and links. For help getting started with CloudFormation, see the\nAWS CloudFormation User Guide.\n\n# AWS::VerifiedPermissions::PolicyStore EncryptionState\n\nA structure that contains the encryption configuration for the policy store and child resources.\n\nThis data type is used as a response parameter field for the GetPolicyStore operation.\n\n## Syntax\n\nTo declare this entity in your CloudFormation template, use the following syntax:\n\n### JSON\n\n`{\n\"Default\" : Json,\n\"KmsEncryptionState\" : KmsEncryptionState\n}`\n`Json`\n`KmsEncryptionState`\n\n### YAML\n\n `Default: Json\nKmsEncryptionState: \nKmsEncryptionState`\n`Json`\n`KmsEncryptionState`\n\n## Properties\n\n`Default`",
      "score": 0.010449656,
      "raw_content": null
    }
  ],

  "request_id": "0d0378e1-8e94-4c85-b087-15be0e736a84"

    {
      "url": "https://www.dayforce.com/who-we-are/newsroom/ceridian-introduces-dayforce-hcm-predictive-analytics",
      "title": "Ceridian Introduces Dayforce HCM Predictive Analytics",
      "content": "Dayforce HCM is a cloud solution for Payroll, Benefits, Workforce Management, Human Resources, Talent Management, Document Management, and Analytics. Built on a single database with one rule engine, Dayforce HCM enables organizations to find and hire the right people, process pay, manage benefits enrollment, maintain HR records, and schedule staff while monitoring compliance throughout the employee lifecycle. Predictive Analytics allows flight-risk data to be embedded throughout the application for easy access and at no additional cost. [...] ---\n\nPRESS RELEASES\n\n# Ceridian Introduces Dayforce HCM Predictive Analytics\n\nData-driven insights help companies identify flight risks and retain high-performing employees\n\nMedia Inquiries\n\nFor all media inquiries, contact us at mediainquiries@dayforce.com\n\nContact us\n\nMinneapolis, MN\nMay 24, 2017\n\nCeridian, a global human capital management technology company, introduces Predictive Analytics, the latest addition to Dayforce HCM – a single application for human capital management. This new capability applies machine learning algorithms to employee data, giving managers and executives a new tool to evaluate employee flight risk and identify and address reasons contributing to employee turnover. [...] “Dayforce HCM has consistently ranked as the leading Leader in our Human Capital Management Value Matrix,” says Brent Skinner, Principal Analyst at Nucleus Research. “This is thanks to Ceridian’s commitment to innovation as they bring full HCM into a single application, with a single dataset governed by a single rules engine. The addition of Predictive Analytics will give Dayforce users the ability to unlock the power of that single dataset for all of HCM. We expect that users will find this new functionality furthering their ability lower costs, boost productivity, improve employee engagement, and reduce turnover.”\n\nFor more information about Predictive Analytics and the entire Dayforce HCM platform, visit www.ceridian.ca.\n\n## You may also like:\n\nView All\n\n Why Dayforce?",

[...] With the fully managed multi-agent collaboration capability on Amazon Bedrock, specialized agents work within their domains of expertise, coordinated by a supervisor agent. The supervisor breaks down requests, delegates tasks, and consolidates outputs into a final response. For example, an investment advisory multi-agent system might include agents specialized in financial data analysis, research, forecasting, and investment recommendations.       "title": "Amazon Bedrock now supports multi-agent collaboration - AWS",
      "content": "# Amazon Bedrock now supports multi-agent collaboration\n\nPosted on: Mar 10, 2025\n\nToday, AWS announces the general availability (GA) of multi-agent collaboration for Amazon Bedrock, allowing developers to create networks of specialized agents that communicate and coordinate under the guidance of a supervisor agent. This new capability allows you to tackle more intricate, multi-step workflows and scale your AI-driven applications more effectively. [...] This release also introduces agent monitoring and observability features, helping you track, monitor, and optimize agent interactions more efficiently. These features improve debugging and traceability, ensuring better visibility into agent workflows and making troubleshooting easier for developers.\n\nMulti-agent collaboration on Amazon Bedrock is now available in all AWS Regions where Amazon Bedrock is supported. To learn more about this feature and how it can help you build more sophisticated AI applications, see the Amazon Bedrock product page or refer to the documentation for detailed information on getting started. [...] Amazon Bedrock multi-agent collaboration GA introduces key enhancements designed to improve scalability, flexibility, and operational efficiency. Inline Agents allow you to dynamically adjust agent roles and behaviors at runtime, making workflows more adaptable as your business needs evolve. With Payload Referencing, supervisor agents can reference linked data instead of embedding it in every request, reducing data transfer, improving response times, and lowering operational costs. Additionally, multi-agent now offers CloudFormation (CFN) and Cloud Development Kit (CDK) support so you can create reusable teams of agents as templates that can be shared across accounts within an organization.",

      "content": "“Using multi-agent collaboration in Amazon Bedrock, customers can get more accurate results by creating and assigning specialized agents for specific steps of a project and accelerate tasks by orchestrating multiple agents working in parallel,” AWS said.\n\nCustomers build their specialized agents on Bedrock, and then make a supervisor or orchestrator agent to help manage the other agents. AWS said the supervisor agent “handles the coordination, like breaking up and routing tasks to the right agents, giving specific agents access to the information they need to complete their work and determining what actions can be processed in parallel.” [...] AWS first introduced agentic capabilities in 2023 with the release of Agents on Bedrock, which offered enterprises a way to start building agents. During its re:Invent event this week, AWS customers like PagerDuty and GitLab announced new agents that let users develop their applications on their platforms and use AWS agents to enhance their workflows.\n\n## Multiple agents becoming the norm [...] All Posts\n\n# AWS brings multi-agent orchestration to Bedrock\n\nEmilia David\n\nAWS is doubling down on AI agents with the announcement of multiagent capabilities on its Amazon Bedrock platform.\n\nDuring his keynote at the AWS re:Invent conference, AWS CEO Matt Garman said customers building agents on Bedrock wanted a means to make agents that work together.",

      "content": "Read more\n\n### How is AI transforming business functions?\n\nOne-third (34%) of surveyed organisations are starting to use AI to deeply transform—creating new products and services or reinventing core processes or business models. Another third (30%) are redesigning key processes around AI. The remaining third (37%) are using AI at a more surface level, with little or no change to existing processes. While each are capturing productivity and efficiency gains, only the first group are truly reimagining their businesses rather than optimising what already exists.\n\nAdditionally, different types of AI technologies yield different expectations for impact.  \n Generative AI (GenAI): The areas of GenAI that leaders believe will have the most impactful effects on their industries are: [...] A financial services company is building agentic workflows to automatically capture meeting actions from video conferences, draft communications to remind participants of their next steps, and track follow-through.\n An air carrier is using AI agents to help customers complete the most common transactions, such as rebooking a flight or rerouting bags, freeing up human agents to address more complex matters.\n A manufacturer is using AI agents to support new product development initiatives, leveraging AI to find the optimal balance between competing objectives such as cost and time-to-market.\n In the public sector, AI agents are being used to cover workforce shortages, partnering with human workers to complete key processes. [...] Leaders are enabling modular, cloud-native platforms that securely connect, govern, and integrate all data types. They break down silos with domain-owned data products and embed privacy, sovereignty, and security-by-design while enforcing enterprise standards for quality, interoperability and lineage.\n A unified, trusted data strategy is indispensable. As businesses evolve and adopt a “best of breed” approach to their enterprise ecosystem, Workday HCM integration with various applications, systems, services and APIs throughout the enterprise is crucial. [...] Many of these systems and applications can be easily integrated natively through Workday, yet many of them require some sort of integration tool be put in place. Businesses have tried to overcome integration challenges by creating custom connectivity and implementing point-to-point integration. This approach applies custom code directly between two endpoints, creating a tightly coupled dependency between them. Although this solution creates connectivity between endpoints, it is limited in complexity due to its fragile nature. Moreover, this method is not future proof; as more and more endpoints need to be integrated, the ecosystem becomes increasingly complex and fragile. [...] ## HCM and Integration Needs\n\nWorkday’s HCM Suite covers an extensive number of applications that merge human resources, talent management, recruiting, benefits and more into a single platform.\n\nWorkday’s HCM Suite helps companies keep their business running, however, today, digital transformation is disrupting the way in which organizations are set up. Businesses are adopting a “best of breed” approach in which they employ applications, systems, and services that have been identified as the best of their type. This method has caused an explosion of endpoints, data sources, and APIs throughout the enterprise, all equally important in helping run the enterprise.\n\n## Common Challenges of HR Integration",

      "content": "Govern the new risks: Biased algorithms. Privacy violations. Inaccurate outputs. Compromised models. AI is powerful, but without governance, it’s just another risk. Build controls to help monitor these risks just as rigorously as you would any other, strive to ensure human oversight where it matters most, and design escalation paths when AI goes off-script. Tip: Take a look at the KPMG AI risk and controls guide to start designing practical controls to help manage your organization’s AI risks. AI is not just a tool for risk management; it is a helpful catalyst for transformation. By moving from siloed solutions to integrated and agentic AI, risk teams can move from hindsight to foresight — spotting emerging threats, modeling complex scenarios, and Conclusion: AI is a helpful catalyst for [...] KPMG Workbench KPMG has collaborated with Microsoft to build KPMG Workbench on Microsoft Azure AI Foundry services, allowing for interoperable, agent-to-agent communications. In addition, it brings together capabilities from across the KPMG ecosystem of alliance partners, such as ServiceNow, Salesforce and Workday, so clients accessing it can choose the model or AI agent that fits their task.       "url": "https://www.workday.com/en-hk/topics/hr/what-is-gardening-leave.html",
      "title": "What is Garden Leave? | Workday HK",
      "content": "Workday provides HR software solutions to help you manage workforce policies, compliance and talent transitions seamlessly whilst ensuring adherence to Hong Kong's employment framework.\n\n## Explore more topics.\n\nHR topics\n\nAI topics\n\nEnterprise resource planning topics\n\n##### Please accept cookies to continue.\n\nThis content is blocked due to your cookie preferences for this site. By clicking here, you accept YouTube's Terms of Service and Policy. Workday will save your choice in a session cookie. [...] In today's fast-paced corporate world, data security and trade secrets are critical and competitors are doing whatever they can to find an edge. This ultimately means businesses must do whatever they can to protect their own interests.\n\nOne such way that employers look to achieve this competitive edge is through a contractual mechanism called 'gardening leave', which acts as a contractual provision that prevents employees from working during their notice period whilst keeping them on full pay.\n\nTable of Contents\n\n## What is gardening leave?\n\nGardening leave refers to the period during which an employee who has resigned or been terminated remains on the company payroll but is not required to be at the workplace or continue working on any projects related to their role. [...] ### Can a company legally force gardening leave?\n\nGardening leave cannot be legally forced by an employer unless the employment contract explicitly states this as a condition. However, if no gardening leave clause exists, the employer has no choice but to either allow the employee to work their agreed notice period or move to negotiate a mutual agreement that is fair to both parties.\n\nWithout a contractual provision, attempting to impose gardening leave could constitute a breach of contract, giving the employee grounds to resign and claim constructive dismissal.\n\n### Should you include a gardening leave clause in your employment contracts?",
      "score": 0.38484335,
      "raw_content": null
    }
  ],
  "response_time": 2.41,
  "request_id": "ca4c26d6-4fc8-446e-a441-ef3c64824d76"

      "url": "https://venturebeat.com/infrastructure/nvidia-groq-and-the-limestone-race-to-real-time-ai-why-enterprises-win-or",
      "title": "Nvidia, Groq and the limestone race to real-time AI - VentureBeat",
      "content": "Read more from our guest post program — and check out our guidelines if you’re interested in contributing an article of your own!\n\n## More [...] ### ​The engine for the next wave of growth\n\n​For the C-Suite, this potential convergence solves the \"thinking time\" latency crisis. Consider the expectations from AI agents: We want them to autonomously book flights, code entire apps and research legal precedent. To do this reliably, a model might need to generate 10,000 internal \"thought tokens\" to verify its own work before it outputs a single word to the user.\n\n ​On a standard GPU: 10,000 thought tokens might take 20 to 40 seconds. The user gets bored and leaves.\n ​On Groq: That same chain of thought happens in less than 2 seconds. [...] ​Training requires massive parallel brute force. Inference, especially for reasoning models, requires faster sequential processing. It must generate tokens instantly to facilitate complex chains of thought without the user waiting minutes for an answer. ​Groq’s LPU (Language Processing Unit) architecture removes the memory bandwidth bottleneck that plagues GPUs during small-batch inference, delivering lightning-fast inference.\n\n### ​The engine for the next wave of growth",

      "url": "https://venturebeat.com/infrastructure/nvidia-groq-and-the-limestone-race-to-real-time-ai-why-enterprises-win-or",
      "title": "Nvidia, Groq and the limestone race to real-time AI - VentureBeat",
      "content": "Read more from our guest post program — and check out our guidelines if you’re interested in contributing an article of your own!\n\n## More [...] ### ​The engine for the next wave of growth\n\n​For the C-Suite, this potential convergence solves the \"thinking time\" latency crisis. Consider the expectations from AI agents: We want them to autonomously book flights, code entire apps and research legal precedent. To do this reliably, a model might need to generate 10,000 internal \"thought tokens\" to verify its own work before it outputs a single word to the user.\n\n ​On a standard GPU: 10,000 thought tokens might take 20 to 40 seconds. The user gets bored and leaves.\n ​On Groq: That same chain of thought happens in less than 2 seconds. [...] ​Training requires massive parallel brute force. Inference, especially for reasoning models, requires faster sequential processing. It must generate tokens instantly to facilitate complex chains of thought without the user waiting minutes for an answer. ​Groq’s LPU (Language Processing Unit) architecture removes the memory bandwidth bottleneck that plagues GPUs during small-batch inference, delivering lightning-fast inference.\n\n### ​The engine for the next wave of growth",
      "score": 0.04725421,
      "raw_content": null
    }

[...] Alliance with Microsoft In addition to building and deploying KPMG Workbench, KPMG and Microsoft entered a multi-year collaboration to put employees and clients at the forefront of the AI revolution. This $28M commitment in Microsoft Cloud and Al Services will unlock potential growth for KPMG of over $12B. Through this global collaboration expansion, We collaborate with the world’s leading AI innovators to drive your success. Our portfolio ecosystem of alliances and startups empower your business with an expansive range of AI capabilities and solutions, seamlessly integrated across multiple platforms. With KPMG, you gain a sustainable competitive edge, powered by the best in tech. [...] Invest in trust-building: AI adoption in risk management isn’t just a technology shift — it’s a culture shift. It will only succeed if your risk professionals trust and embrace AI insights. Help overcome resistance or skepticism by quickly demonstrating how AI tools can help improve accuracy and results — or simply make your teams’ daily work easier. You can also involve your risk managers in co-developing AI workflows with AI specialists. It should help them feel confident models are not only technically sound, but also align with their expertise and mesh with their processes. Tip: Use targeted training programs for risk managers to build confidence and foster a culture that embraces AI, not fears it.",

Talent is a major constraint across APAC and Europe. Several CIOs describe IT workforces heavily skewed toward maintaining legacy systems, with aging skills on mainframe or niche platforms and limited internal capacity for data science or AI engineering. A regional bank, for example, is creating a new workforce management function that spans enterprise architecture, financial rigor on tech spend, and talent planning. A university CIO is hiring for new enterprise architecture and emerging technology roles. In parallel, several firms hit by cyberattacks are using resilience programs as a catalyst to rebalance teams toward centralized security, platform engineering, and automation skills. CIOs are shifting the mix of skills, [...] Many organizations run on hybrid models that were never designed: project teams layered over product teams layered over business lines, with no clear decision rights and thin enterprise architecture (EA) capability. Talent is skewed toward keeping legacy systems alive, with limited capacity for innovation, data, and AI. Several leaders are also facing cost constraints, static or shrinking headcount, and cultural resistance to new ways of working or to AI-driven change.\n\nFrom guidance kickoff (GKO) conversations, three initiative patterns recur when CIOs talk about evolving operating models and talent:",

      "content": "Workday provides HR software solutions to help you manage workforce policies, compliance and talent transitions seamlessly whilst ensuring adherence to Hong Kong's employment framework.\n\n## Explore more topics.\n\nHR topics\n\nAI topics\n\nEnterprise resource planning topics\n\n##### Please accept cookies to continue.\n\nThis content is blocked due to your cookie preferences for this site. By clicking here, you accept YouTube's Terms of Service and Policy. Workday will save your choice in a session cookie. [...] It is critical that the company does not try to reduce the employee's remuneration or entitlements during this notice period, as this opens the organisation up to legal challenges for breaches of the employment contract and potential claims under the Employment Ordinance.\n\nGardening leave is particularly common in Hong Kong's financial services sector and other industries where employees have access to commercially sensitive information. Many of which Workday serves as core industries, including:\n\n Banking and financial services\n Technology and IT\n Legal and consulting firms\n Media and advertising\n Private equity and investment management\n\n## Frequently asked questions.\n\n### How long does a period of gardening leave last? [...] Employment rights remain intact: Employees placed on gardening leave must still receive their salary, all benefits and entitlements, including bonuses (if applicable under their contract). Employers cannot reduce remuneration during this period.\n Legal protections: If gardening leave is deemed to be unfairly enforced or if the employer breaches the employment contract, an employee may have grounds for a legal challenge through the Labour Tribunal or civil courts in Hong Kong.",

Understanding gardening leave in Hong Kong. [...] In today's fast-paced corporate world, data security and trade secrets are critical and competitors are doing whatever they can to find an edge. This ultimately means businesses must do whatever they can to protect their own interests.\n\nOne such way that employers look to achieve this competitive edge is through a contractual mechanism called 'gardening leave', which acts as a contractual provision that prevents employees from working during their notice period whilst keeping them on full pay.\n\nTable of Contents\n\n## What is gardening leave?\n\nGardening leave refers to the period during which an employee who has resigned or been terminated remains on the company payroll but is not required to be at the workplace or continue working on any projects related to their role.",

      "title": "Openflowについて | Snowflake Documentation",
      "content": "Openflow - Bring Your Own Cloud (BYOC) provides a connectivity solution that you can use\nto connect public and private systems securely and handle sensitive data preprocessing\nlocally, within the secure bounds of your organization's cloud environment.\nBYOC refers to a deployment option where the Openflow data\nprocessing engine, or data plane, runs within your own cloud environment\nwhile Snowflake manages the overall Openflow service and control plane.\n\nBYOC デプロイメントを構成する場合は、Openflowの設定 - BYOC で説明されているプロセスに従ってください。\n\n## ユースケース¶\n\n任意のソースからデータをフェッチし、最小限の管理で任意の宛先にデータを配置する場合は、Snowflakeの組み込みデータセキュリティおよびガバナンスと合わせて、Openflowを使用します。\n\nOpenflowのユースケースは次のとおりです。\n\nGoogle DriveやBoxなどの非構造化データソースからデータを取り込み、Snowflake Cortexを使用してAIアシスタントでチャットにできるようにしたり、独自のカスタム処理にデータを使用したりできます。 [...] データベーステーブルの変更データキャプチャ（CDC）をSnowflakeに複製し、包括的で一元化されたレポートを作成します。\n\nApache KafkaなどのストリーミングサービスからリアルタイムイベントをSnowflakeに取り込み、ほぼリアルタイムの分析ができます。\n\nLinkedIn Adsなどの SaaS プラットフォームからデータを取り込み、Snowflakeでレポート、分析、インサイトに使用します。\n\nSnowflakeならびに NiFi プロセッサー および :doc:`コントローラーサービス<controllers/index>`を使用して、Openflowデータフローを作成します。\n\n## セキュリティ¶\n\nOpenflowは業界最先端のセキュリティ機能を使用しており、アカウント、ユーザー、およびSnowflakeに保存するすべてのデータに対して最高レベルのセキュリティを確保できます。重要な要素は次のとおりです。\n\nランタイムはSnowflakeへの認証に OAuth2 を使用します。\n\nOpenflowでは、RBACの詳細なロール設定に対応しています\n\nACCOUNTADMINでは、デプロイメントとランタイムを作成できる権限を付与します。\n\nOpenflowコネクタは TLS プロトコルをサポートしており、データ取り込みにSnowflake標準クライアントを使用します。\n\nOpenflowのデプロイメントとOpenflowのコントロールプレーン間のすべての通信は、TLS プロトコルを使用して暗号化されます。\n\nAWS Secrets ManagerまたはHashicorp Vaultと統合しています。詳細については、 構成ファイルの暗号化パスワード をご覧ください。 [...] Openflowはデータ統合のための標準的なセキュリティ、コンプライアンス、可観測性、保守性フックを提供します。\n\n1つの統一プラットフォームにより、事実上あらゆる規模で、データソースからSnowflakeへ、バッチモードとストリーミングモードの両方で構造化、非構造化データを処理できます。\n\nほぼリアルタイムでの非構造化データのインジェスチョンにより、SharePointやGoogle Driveなどのソースからのデータと即座にチャットできます。\n\n## Openflowデプロイメントタイプ¶\n\nOpenflowは、Bring Your Own Cloud（BYOC）バージョンとSnowpark Container Services（SPCS）バージョンの両方でサポートされています。\n\nSnowflakeのロゴ（黒）（文字なし） Feature --- Generally Available\n\nSnowflakeのロゴ（黒）（文字なし）\n\nSnowflake Openflow - Snowflakeデプロイメントは、AWS およびAzure Commercial regions のすべてのアカウントで利用できます。",
      "score": 0.036456086,
      "raw_content": null

      "content": "KPMG Workbench KPMG has collaborated with Microsoft to build KPMG Workbench on Microsoft Azure AI Foundry services, allowing for interoperable, agent-to-agent communications. In addition, it brings together capabilities from across the KPMG ecosystem of alliance partners, such as ServiceNow, Salesforce and Workday, so clients accessing it can choose the model or AI agent that fits their task. [...] AI can help deliver transformative value across various stages of the risk management lifecycle, from risk identification to risk review and reporting. Here are some not-so-obvious use cases your organization can start exploring right now: AI use cases through the risk management lifecycle Risk identification: AI can generate process flows, detect emerging risks, and recommend mappings to risk taxonomies, processes, and controls. This helps organizations identify risks more accurately and earlier.\nRisk assessment: AI can recommend risk ratings, generate and monitor key risk indicators, and calculate residual risk. By making risk assessment more probabilistic, AI can enhance the precision and consistency of risk ratings. [...] Risk mitigation: AI tools can support decision-making around risk response strategies and automate or enhance mitigation actions. For instance, they can identify issues and root causes, review and design control inventories, and monitor alerts more efficiently and precisely.\nRisk monitoring: AI enables real-time or continuous monitoring of risk indicators, producing aggregated reporting and moving from point-in-time reporting to more dynamic, real-time capabilities.\nRisk review and reporting: AI helps improve the efficiency and quality of risk reporting by automating the generation of reports, thematic analysis, and standardized risk and control report outputs.",

      "content": "Credit: VentureBeat made with Midjourney\n\n## Anthropic’s Claude Cowork finally lands on Windows — and it wants to automate your workday\n\nThe Windows launch arrives with what Anthropic calls \"full feature parity\" with the macOS version: file access, multi-step task execution, plugins, and Model Context Protocol (MCP) connectors for integrating external services.       "url": "https://venturebeat.com/infrastructure/nvidia-groq-and-the-limestone-race-to-real-time-ai-why-enterprises-win-or",
      "title": "Nvidia, Groq and the limestone race to real-time AI - VentureBeat",
      "content": "Read more from our guest post program — and check out our guidelines if you’re interested in contributing an article of your own!\n\n## More [...] ### ​The engine for the next wave of growth\n\n​For the C-Suite, this potential convergence solves the \"thinking time\" latency crisis. Consider the expectations from AI agents: We want them to autonomously book flights, code entire apps and research legal precedent. To do this reliably, a model might need to generate 10,000 internal \"thought tokens\" to verify its own work before it outputs a single word to the user.\n\n ​On a standard GPU: 10,000 thought tokens might take 20 to 40 seconds. The user gets bored and leaves.\n ​On Groq: That same chain of thought happens in less than 2 seconds. [...] ​Training requires massive parallel brute force. Inference, especially for reasoning models, requires faster sequential processing. It must generate tokens instantly to facilitate complex chains of thought without the user waiting minutes for an answer. ​Groq’s LPU (Language Processing Unit) architecture removes the memory bandwidth bottleneck that plagues GPUs during small-batch inference, delivering lightning-fast inference.\n\n### ​The engine for the next wave of growth",
      "score": 0.04725421,

Understanding gardening leave in Hong Kong. [...] In today's fast-paced corporate world, data security and trade secrets are critical and competitors are doing whatever they can to find an edge. This ultimately means businesses must do whatever they can to protect their own interests.\n\nOne such way that employers look to achieve this competitive edge is through a contractual mechanism called 'gardening leave', which acts as a contractual provision that prevents employees from working during their notice period whilst keeping them on full pay.\n\nTable of Contents\n\n## What is gardening leave?\n\nGardening leave refers to the period during which an employee who has resigned or been terminated remains on the company payroll but is not required to be at the workplace or continue working on any projects related to their role.",

Request payload
